Did you know that living an active lifestyle can improve many aspects of your life, including academic performance? Studies show that exercise and being active at least 60 minutes a day can lead to improved focus, better sleep, and improved moods. These three things together can only help your child in a school setting. Being active doesn’t have to be limited to running and lifting weights. There are so many ways that your child can stay active including dancing, walking a dog, or even just playing outside with their friends. As a school we are always looking for ways to help our students succeed in all aspects of life. That is why our school partners with the Move your way campaign to help encourage our students to be active for at least 60 minutes a day.

Attached is the flyer for the Move your way campaign, and all their ideas of ways to keep your children active!

https://health.gov/sites/default/files/2019-11/PAG_MYW_Parents_FS.pdf

post_text: Every year our middle school students learn about the tragic events that occurred on September 11th, 2001. This lesson always seems to spark a tremendous amount of questions, discussion and student engagement in my classroom. At the end of the lesson students walk away with a much stronger respect for the first responders in our own community who put their lives on the line every day. Students choose to write cards or letters to the men and women of our military, EMS, police and fire departments. Our first responders are very appreciative of the support. We are proud of how our Reach scholars have developed an understanding of the importance of these occupations. Thank you to our everyday heroes! A special thanks to the Roseville Police Department, Roseville Fire Department, Universal Macomb Ambulance, Luke Dickerson and all the members of our National Guard.
